title: Laws of Offerings
shortSummary: Leviticus chapter 6 details specific laws regarding sin, trespass, burnt, meat, and sin offerings. It emphasizes the importance of restitution, atonement, and the proper procedures for priests in maintaining holiness before the LORD. This chapter highlights God's holiness and the necessity of obedience in worship and community relationships.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Wilderness Period after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The mediator between God and Israel who receives and conveys God's instructions regarding offerings and priestly duties.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: The high priest and brother of Moses, responsible for performing the offerings and maintaining the altar fire as commanded.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron's Sons
keyCharacters.description: Assistants to Aaron who share in the duties of offering sacrifices and eating the designated portions of offerings.

definitions.definition: A sacrifice made to atone for unintentional sins involving wrongdoing against others or God, requiring restitution plus an additional fifth part.
A sacrifice completely consumed by fire on the altar, symbolizing total dedication and atonement to God.
A grain offering made of fine flour and oil, partially burned on the altar as a sweet savor to the LORD, with the remainder eaten by priests.
A sacrifice made to atone for sins, especially those affecting the community or the sanctuary, with specific regulations for its handling and consumption.

outline.heading: Instructions for Trespass Offering and Restitution
outline.description: God commands restitution plus a fifth part for sins involving deceit or wrongful taking, followed by a ram as a trespass offering to atone and bring forgiveness.

outline.heading: The Law of the Burnt Offering
outline.description: Detailed instructions for priests on maintaining the altar fire continuously and handling the ashes, emphasizing the perpetual nature of worship and God's holiness.

outline.heading: The Law of the Meat Offering
outline.description: Regulations for the grain offering, including its preparation, the portion burned on the altar, and the portion eaten by priests, highlighting its sacredness and role in worship.

outline.heading: The Law of the Sin Offering
outline.description: Instructions for the sin offering's place of slaughter, consumption by priests, and the sanctity of anything that touches it, underscoring the seriousness of sin and the need for purification.

application: Confess and make restitution promptly when you have wronged others, reflecting biblical justice and repentance.
Approach God with reverence and obedience, recognizing the holiness required in worship and service.
Trust in Christ as the ultimate atonement fulfilling the sacrificial system, and live a life dedicated to Godâ€™s service.
Maintain spiritual vigilance and consistency in prayer and worship, just as the altar fire was to be kept burning continually.

keyVerses.text: Or all that about which he hath sworn falsely; he shall even restore it in the principal, and shall add the fifth part more thereto, and give it unto him to whom it appertaineth, in the day of his trespass offering.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the biblical principle of restitution and the seriousness of sin against others, requiring both repayment and an additional penalty.

keyVerses.text: The fire shall ever be burning upon the altar; it shall never go out.
keyVerses.significance: This verse symbolizes the continual presence of God and the unceasing nature of worship and devotion required from His people.

keyVerses.text: And the priest shall make an atonement for him before the LORD: and it shall be forgiven him for any thing of all that he hath done in trespassing therein.
keyVerses.significance: It underscores the role of the priest as mediator and the provision of forgiveness through proper sacrifice.

keyVerses.text: The priest that offereth it for sin shall eat it: in the holy place shall it be eaten, in the court of the tabernacle of the congregation.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows the sacred privilege and responsibility of priests in handling sin offerings, emphasizing holiness and reverence.
